I am a fan of breakfast. Especially unique, high quality options in an eclectic environment. Marigold's delivers. In fact, I am hesitant to try other breakfast options. We went to a local crepe place in Madison this weekend. They did a decent job but it was not a breakfast I would return for. If you want a menu that varies but holds on to local favorites, and has excellent coffee/latte/etc options, even mimosa's on Sundays (maybe everyday, we always go on Sunday morning) give this place a try. They have a to go option but I love getting a spot at the counter and feeling the breakfast vibe! Your plate arrives with the kind of breakfast you want to make at home-and it only gets better when someone makes it for you!!

This place is a headache.  I went on a Saturday morning for brunch and there was so much noise and hustle.  Definitely did not like that aspect.  The food is good.  I ordered French toast and a scrambler to share.  The French toast came with fresh fruit and tasted super yummy.  The scrambler portion was small, but very tasty!  Perhaps the potatoes were too drenched in oil because they were orange in color.    The service is decent.  The girls at the register are nicer.  I would like to return, but on a quieter day.

The food is good. Place is cozy.  Everything's a bit expensive.  The smell inside is heavenly. Lots of hipsters and groups of Sophmore/Junior UW girls.  Try the weekend brunch. Try the pumpkin pancakes. Try anything from the omelette lineup.

Really good food and coffee (I got lemon ricotta pancakes) but they have a bad seating system. They were super busy so you order at the counter and then stand on the side until there's an open table. My friend's food was cold but still really good. Weird service but I'd still recommend going here.

Love it! Such Amazing Food!!!  Breakfast sandwich is wonderful and service is delightful. Came here while in town for just a few days and sort of fell in love with the atmosphere.   Lovely food and people. Coffee and tea is top notch and everything on the menu is fresh/creative/organic/local. The prices are also very reasonable considering the portions.

Just stopping in yesterday morning.  I haven't been in a couple of years, so it was exciting to return.   We ordered the chile poached eggs on toast with coffee.  Presentation was beautiful, 2 perfect white eggs with chile flakes.  It looked amazing but size wise I was a little disappointed.  Food tasted perfect.  Coffee was perfect.   Overall glad for the visit but a little bummed that it was not a WOW experience.
Nice brunch atmosphere, friendly service. Welcoming to kids. Very good quiche. Potatoes a little spicier than expected.

I like this place most for its high-quality food, variety of options, and cozy atmosphere. They serve great vegetarian options, but I hear their angus burger is really good.   It's a warm, unpretentious, and civilized place to meet with friends, and eat good food. If you're a student the price range may not fall within your list of daily go-to places, but it would definitely be top on my list if I am looking for a nice place to go with friends or family.   P.S. The coffee is delicious and unlimited!

Came here for lunch while visiting the university.  There is only one vegetarian sandwich on the menu, but its delicious. I was skeptical of something with beets, curried chickpeas, and apples, but it turned out that those flavors go together perfectly.

All around positive Saturday morning Brunch experience here. Yes, there was a line-but the wait was not bad-friendly gal distributed menus and managed crowd well. Once inside, the folks taking the order were super-efficient and Madison friendly. My son ordered the breakfast sandwich, my wife had an omelette and I did the standard 2 eggs over easy. The potatoes were amazing, eggs great, fresh-squeezed OJ delicious, sandwich and omelette got rave reviews. The experience eating here was perfect. Everything a breakfast should be. Can't wait to go back again next UW visit.
I love this place, but today, I got a to-go order and my soup was only 2/3 filled. Not happy.
Terrific food and great atmosphere. Excellent egg nog latte, fabulous scrambled eggs and tasty breakfast potatoes. I love breakfast and this was outstanding.

I love the food at this restaurant so much I would've given it five stars if I could rate the food apart from other aspects of the restaurant. I knocked it down one because one gripe is that the line to even order can extend out the door. And once you've ordered, it may take a short wait to get a table if it is significantly busy, which is usually the case. I guess that is an artifact of having food that people want. I also prefer a restaurant that is a bit more spacious, quiet and has more private feeling seating. (E.g, booth seating). For many people I understand that these things will not be an issue. It also doesn't necessarily deter me from coming to this restaurant but once I'm done eating I usually leave immediately. You can't go wrong with the French toast. Nor can you go wrong with the egg sandwich spiked with Boursin.

I wasn't too satisfied when I first came to Marigold Kitchen for a Sunday brunch. Even though we were told over the phone that the crowds "weren't that bad," it was a complete shitshow in there. Busboys fighting through the crowds to get to tables, a line going from the counter to the door, background noise so loud that you have to scream what you want to order, and a restaurant that was way too small to contain it all. They haven't done a very good job at all managing these crowds and maximizing their available space.  Not helping Marigold is the fact that you have to order your food from the counter and take a number, and that they can't even be bothered to bring your drinks out to you. I had to get water from a jug on a table placed in the worst spot imaginable (right next to the counter), where I couldn't even move my elbows. And despite the massive line, the girl taking orders at the counter didn't seem to have any issue with having a long conversation with anyone who was placing an order.   While ordering from a counter would ultimately save you money on tip, the savings are balanced out by the price of the food itself. You'll pay just as much as you would for sit-down service at another breakfast joint.  So, given the abhorrent service, you're probably wondering how my rating is so high. The fact is, when you serve food this good, you can abuse your customers like this and they'll enjoy it. Seriously, this is some of the best breakfast food I have ever had.  I ordered a special called "The Scrambler," which was scrambled eggs mixed up with cheese and vegetables. The eggs were cooked perfectly, with a fluffy consistency that is practically nonexistent at any other restaurant. I also got French rosemary toast and their signature "Marigold Potatoes" on the side.   While the toast was unique, it wasn't anything special. The potatoes were incredible. I don't know what they do to them to make them so soft and so crispy at the same time, or what spices made them taste so perfect. You have to try it, and fortunately, it comes with almost every dish they serve.  I also ordered some thick and fluffy buttermilk pancakes which were topped with a sweet mango butter. However, they served it with a pathetic amount of syrup. I had to substitute the lack of sweetness with the jam on the table, which was incredibly fresh. It was definitely made in the restaurant, without the addition of massive amounts of sugar.  The jam is like every other ingredient Marigold uses. Everything tastes fresh and organic, like they were growing the food right there in their kitchen. The prices and crowds here are easily justified by the fact that when you order food from Marigold Kitchen, you know that they're going to serve you nothing but food made from the very highest quality of ingredients.
Amazing place for breakfast. Lovely environment, nice music on the background and delicious food. I had the bacon spinach omelet and it was amazing. I loved the homemade potatoes as a side.
Superb breakfast. French toast was excellent.  Rest of the table had the daily specials.  They were also impressive.
I would call marigold kitchen a typical hipster farm to table restaurant. But the food is excellent. It's alway very busy, so give yourself plenty of time.

I've had several friends highly recommend the Marigold Kitchen, so we decided to try it for lunch this week. We got there a little before noon and there was a line to the door. Ordering takes place a the counter and they have menus to peruse while you are waiting in line. The menu consists of breakfast items as well as sandwiches, salads, and soups for lunch. I decided on the Marigold Italian: Salami, Spicy Capicola ham, aioli, provolone, and frisée with a pickled vegetable relish on a toasted baguette. We arrived at the counter, placed our order, got a number, and found a table to wait for our drinks and meals to arrive.  My companion had the Mushroom and Provolone Grilled Cheese: roasted mushroom relish, basil walnut pesto, and roasted tomato on grilled rustic bread and said it was very good. My sandwich arrived and was accompanied by a purple slaw with a light vinaigrette. The slaw was pretty and fresh but definitely needed some lemon juice and salt to jazz it up a bit. My sandwich looked great, lot of fresh, quality ingredients, but when I bit into it, I tasted something salty, bitter, and off-tasting. I opened my sandwich and realized there were dozens of chopped olives. Perhaps I should have realized pickled vegetable relish meant olives but unfortunately I did not. (I was picturing pickled peppers, carrots, cauliflower, etc) I don't think of olives as being a vegetable. I have a strong dislike of olives and if I would have realized olives were on the sandwich I never would have ordered it. I tried my best to pick them off but I kept biting into them buried in the frisée or the aioli. This pretty much ruined the sandwich and the meal for me.  If you are not a picky eater, you'll probably enjoy the Marigold Kitchen. The food was fresh, the servers polite. I was just disappointed by the olive surprise.

Duck confit hash, meet my stomach. Stomach, meet duck confit hash.  Every weekend, a new place pops up to contend for the prestigious "best brunch Peter has ever had in Madison" award, and Marigold has put everyone on notice.  From their freshly roasted endless coffee, to their rich, fatty duck confit, to the crispy, thin potato skins, to the warm, buttery milk pancakes, each and every dish was executed to perfection.   While I loved my dish, the French Toast some of my friends got definitely caught my eyes (brunch next weekend, anyone?).   This place doesn't have too much seating, so try getting here early and grabbing a spot.   All in all, another fantastic location to add to my ever growing list of must try brunch places in Madison.

This place delicious, went for breakfast while in Madison. House made chai was tasty (sweet but not too sweet). Had the specials..scramble with sausage, mushrooms and tomato. So good! Potatoes are really good. Husband had the granola pancakes and those were really good as well.

This restaurant is very cute and is very popular for brunch on Sundays.  Someone recommended this restaurant to me, and I am very glad that she did!   I went around 1130 on a Sunday and it was pretty crowded.  The hostess doesn't seat you at this restaurant,  you actually look over the menu and the specials boards, order at the register and then they bring your food out to you, wherever you find seating .  This is actually a pretty great setup, but my group only consisted of three people, with more people you may have a harder time getting enough seats, as the restaurant is not very big. They do also have outside seating, but it was mostly 4 person tables outside.  They have great brunch choices, complete with any brunch worthy alcoholic beverage. I had a mimosa (yum!) and we also got a glass of the fresh strawberry lemonade (super yum! And you can actually add alcohol to it if you'd like). I ordered one of their epic sounding omelettes and it was actually one of the best omelettes that I have ever had. Service was great, everyone was totally friendly. Overall a really great place to grab brunch.  I would recommend it to anyone hanging around in Madison. This is also very close to the Capitol, so the view and location are terrific!

Every time we visit, food has been consistently good!!! We had the chorizo omelet and the cocoa pancake. Both were wonderful. The cocoa pancake was a chocolate lovers dream!! It came streaming hot and it taste perfect. The service is fast and friendly.

I've been going to Marigold since it opened and am a fan.  I love their french toast and when they have it, pancakes with the marscapone cheese.  YUM.    Their eggs and potatoes and toast are also good and cheap.  Totally worth it.  Get the sourdough.  I think the french toast, the scramblers and most other dishes are overpriced.  Hence the reason why I usually just get the eggs sans meat.  I guess it isn't really a Marigold thing, most restaurants in Madison seem to be overpriced.    I do appreciate their cheap, tasty kids meals for the kiddos.  $1.95!    They could seriously improve their customer service.  I've had issues with gift cards, them forgetting my order completely and they are ALWAYS messing up an order.  These aren't special orders--just whatever is on the menu, no subs.  They do not go out of their way to make things right because as everyone else says, they are always packed.  I wish that they would re-think their ordering system.  It's fine IF everyone knows to not grab a table until you have ordered!  Otherwise, you are standing there with your food with no seat.

Unimpressed with the grilled chicken salad. Chicken was dry with no seasonings and burnt on the edges. Vinegrette was bland and they didn't put enough on the salad. Not a reasonable portion size for the $12 it cost. Many better places to choose from around the Capitol.

The last time I checked out the menu for Marigold, it didn't look like there were a lot of options for a Madison vegan... well, I went with friends for brunch, and I had grapefruit juice, the tofu scramble, and the almond mocha latte and was satisfied and happy (I did steal some fried potatoes from my husband.) The scramble was delicious with avocado added. My omni friends and family were very happy (kids can split a short stack!) I will most definitely be back!

I was more impressed the second time around. I still wouldn't say the BEST brunch place but it is pretty good. I ordered a classic American breakfast, two eggs, toast and potatoes. The eggs were cooked well and the potatoes were pretty tasty. I visited a few days before Christmas and they were handing out free egg nog which packed quite an alcoholic punch.

Wonderful restaurant - great food and fun lively atmosphere.  It is alwasy busy unless you can wait til after 1pm for lunch.  The space was designed by the same architect who designed the rest of the block.    I especially love the salads and burgers.  The flavor can't be beat.

i felt very blah about my food.  i feel bad because i wasn't in the best of mood for brunch food, but am trying to rate without that in mind.  now, mind my snobiness, but we have some damn good brunch in chicago, and unfortunately this place just couldn't live up to my windy city standards.  the pancakes were good but a bit flat for my taste - as in, not poofy.  i know this is the new pancake fashion, flat cakes with compote of some sort, but it wasn't wow-ing.  the potatoes were okay, extremely greasy and IMO not seasoned well, instead depending on its spicy greasy sauce instead.  whatever.  anyway, the boyfriend seemed to enjoy my pancakes much more than i did, but wasn't thrilled with his special scrambler.  unfortunately it was made with lots of green onion and the potatoes have them, as well, so it was a little too much green onion overall.  the jam sitting out on the table was delicious and coffee was good, too.  overall good, but not wowing.

So, we came to Madison for a day and we had heard great news about this place. The line was relatively long but it went by quick. The entire staff were super friendly and that was a plus. We had to wait to be seated since it was a full house, we were in no rush, ultimately, but when we sat down and waited nearly 40 minutes, that's we stayed getting impatient. I'm not a big meal person for breakfast, so I was highly upset that I waited that long for some pancakes  the service was excellent tho!!

I had a tasty, healthy lunch here! I had a tuna melt sandwich with the red cabbage slaw, and my friend had the beetnik with potato salad. I was looking for something hearty and found that the tuna melt definitely satisfied my craving. The tuna tasted pretty fresh, and the sandwich had just the right amount of cheese. The red cabbage slaw was fresh and crunchy.  The environment is cozy, warm, and well-decorated. It was pretty busy during lunchtime.  Her beetnik looked delicious, and I was trying to go back on a Saturdday to try it out... but then I forgot that it was brunch on weekends during lunchtime! Foiled.

Marigold Kitchen is a solid lunch location.  The staff are nice, the restaurant ambiance is pleasant, and the food is really quite good for the price.  The only thing I wish for the lunch menu is that there were a few more vegetarian options.  Though the vegetarian options they do have are delicious and keep me coming back.

I go to bed looking forward to breakfast. If someone informs me that they do not eat breakfast-- I take that as an open invitation to force my belief of the importance of breakfast upon them.   That being said, I'm a creature of habit. I have the same things each morning and RARELY will give them up for eggs, omelettes, scramblers, etc., which often leave me feeling full, lethargic, and disappointed.  Enter Marigold Kitchen: Your breakfast sandwich is amazing (fried egg, cheddar-spiked boursin, applewood smoked bacon, tomato and green onion on toasted ciabatta). It's the perfect combination of all the right flavors. Greasy? Heavy? Absolutely not. Incredibly rich? Yes.  It will be crowded on Saturday and Sunday mornings, but the staff does a surprisingly good job at moving people through and clearing tables.
Chaotic and poor service.... Better yet no service. Cashier was rude and unhelpful. Great food or not won't be returning.
AMAZING!!!  The scrambler is unmatched and those marigold potatoes... Wow. You must go here.

Great vibes! It's fun to watch the line cooks busy behind the counter.   My man and I split the duck confit, which was delicious but pretty pricey for the portion size. The ingredients were all cooked perfectly and the flavors were well-balanced. The dressing for the greens had a nice acidity to offset the richness of the eggs. A good choice for those who like a savory breakfast. I would recommend getting toast on the side.  I would also highly recommend trying a signature coffee drink. The Cafe Miel was warm, comforting, and just sweet enough. The mint espresso drink (the name is escaping me) is also delicious.   And if you're a sucker for pastries like I am, they have really good scones!

Counter service only, coffee shop with GREAT breakfast!  Best potatoes I've ever had at a restaurant. Huge omelette well stuffed. Generous portions. Salmon frittata with lots of greens on top. Great bread.

Love the food - not a fan of the atmosphere though.  The blueberry pancakes with the orange butter are fabulous and have completely changed the way I make pancakes at home.  I also love the breakfast sandwich - so good!  The one thing I don't like about the place is how loud it is - the acoustics of the place just seem to amplify everything and it gets too loud for me to really enjoy if it's super busy.

Solid brunch spot. It's always crowded on the weekends so expect a line.  They're famous for the potatoes which are good but very very oily. They're flavoring comes mostly from being slathered in chili oil or something like that but they're a little crispy as well which is why I like them.   I got the chili poached eggs once which is a really small serving but tasted better than okay.   The three grain saute is good, a little oily.   I rarely get sandwiches from anywhere, but I loved Marigold's hearty sandwiches before I was a vegetarian.

Run,  don't walk!  Found this place, on Yelp, to put something yummy in our tummies after visiting the Dells. Happy to say,  we scored.   You can choose to order off the menu- you can grab one as you walk in- or off the special board above the register,  either way,  you can't miss.   Started with a YUMMY and naturally alkalizing Switchel. Refreshing!  Ordered the quiche, which was delicious, though I like my eggs with a bit more salt and a side of greens, really tasty and fresh.  The chilaquiles were also delish, added a little hot sauce for an extra kick and a side of perfectly spiced potatoes (just a touch on the spicy side), yes, I'm a wimp.   Left with one of the best latte's I've ever had. All in all, great choice if you enjoy real food and a cool staff.  Prices are comparable and fair. We will be back!

First time here, even though I walk by it almost every day.  So glad I finally stopped for breakfast before Farmer's Market.   The place had excellent chilaquiles.  We also shared toasted almond pancakes which were wonderful.

Yummmmmm! I am a fan of this place! I think it definitely beats out basset street brunch and is equally as good as lazy janes.  Come early! Or just find the right time in between the rush because this place will have a line out the door before you know it and you'll be standing against the walls waiting for your food instead of at a table. Speaking of food--  I got the scrambler which changes/has additions depending on the day. Originally i really wanted to try the monte cristo after reading some reviews but alas that was the special sandwich for the day and they had moved along. Sooo note! Don't get attached to the special....   The scrambler was good! Potatoes were super tasty as well as the salad on the side. Portion was decent, I think it was probably the perfect size, but man was I hungry. So I def wanted more. I liked all the veggies in it and honestly I think it just needed a little more cheese. The OJ was super fresh and delish so def get it   My friend got the duck confit hash and that was super tasty! A little fatty but come on, that's what gives it the flavor. I'll be back to try more menu items but so far I'm a fan!   Happy brunching!

I often have breakfast at Marigold Kitchen on my trips to Madison. The place still does not disappoint. The food is fresh and the breakfast dishes innovative. For a cholesterol break, I have their tofu scramble. And yes, they make tofu tasty. It's a great place to sit and sip a latte and read the morning paper before the hectic day begins.

Omelette with pesto sauce was delicious but fairly small for the $13 price. Highly recommend the fruit cup sub.. very fresh and nice size for small upcharge. Poppyseed Scone was super hard and dry. Mimosas are tasty as well.

Cheery decor. Partly self serve. High prices. Not too extensive a menu. Good coffee. Pleasant service. Chilaquiles were not very good; overcooked and too much cheese. Don't understand why this place is so well rated.

Voted best breakfast in Madison in 2015, and I can say that it definitely lived up to the hype!   Don't let the long line deter you. You order at the counter, grab your number, and then wait for the hostess to seat you. I found this very appealing because you don't have everyone scrambling to grab a table or people breathing down your neck while you're eating; instead the hostess handles it! Problem solved.   I ordered the half order of the Buckwheat pancakes, which was only $4! The pancakes themselves were good, and they were topped with candied pecans and bananas, but the cinnamon butter was the STAR of the show. My goodness, that butter plus a little syrup made the whole dish something out of my wildest dreams. I also ordered the cold brew coffee (made from Colectivo!) for $3 and was such a happy camper!   Delicious Food + Cheap Prices = Repeat Visit.  I would easily come back here for brunch over and over again.

This place is easy to miss, but once you're in, you're hooked.  Cafe style ordering, with ordering at the counter, taking a number.  Nice part - wait staff checks on you once seated.  Now onto the gold part of marigold...Beet sandwich was so fresh and delicious tasting.  The portobello mushroom sandwich was the perfectly cheesy, yet light.  All the salads are pretty damn good.  Bloody Mary's are spicy and not too salty.  Coffee tastes fresh and is local.  All in all, a great place to grab a bite to eat, have brunch, or just chow down/sip while enjoying your paper.  There was a huge lunch rush around 1pm and it got packed fast, so either come before or after.
Duck hash, oatmeal and coffee were all good. Not a bad place for some nice brunch.

Best breakfast!  Marigold makes the most lovely egg dishes, complete with lightly dressed fresh greens, toast, and potatoes.  Their sourdough bread is an absolute winner.  They cook eggs to perfection:  done but soft, delightfully flavored by creative combinations of ingredients.  My favourite breakfast and brunch spot in Madison, and one of my top places in the world.  (I'm kind of a major breakfast groupie.)

This is probably my favorite brunch place in Madison.   Marigold Kitchen has different specials from season to season and changes pretty often. Most of these specials are pretty good. As for their regular brunch menu, I think my favorite items from here are their omelettes, and I do believe I've tried them all. They offer healthy and appetizing ingredients, and somehow they just make them better than other places. My favorite is the one with zucchini and goat cheese. Other than the omelettes, the french toast and the quiches here are also scrumptious.   I've never been here on a weekday, but I can assure you that brunch on Saturdays and Sundays requires you to wait quite a bit. Try to go before 10 AM or after 2 PM.

Delicious!!! Very friendly staff... thank you for offering vegan options! The beet and Fuji Thai Peanut sandwich was amazing!  We were passing by Madison on a road trip and I called in my order and we were able swing by to pick it up and keep on our way. Parking was a bit tricky though, just be aware it is downtown and that always makes parking interesting!

As for brunch in Madison, I go to Mickie's when I am on a budget and near UW campus; travel to Original Pancake House on the west side if I am hungry and look for a family friendly relaxed setting. But when craving for good brunch food, Marigold Kitchen is my only choice.   I always have mixed feeling about the humongous brunch in other places. On the one hand, it is good bang of my buck; on the other hand, it makes me over-eat and sleep in food coma afterwards. I found Marigold serve just enough food that really energizes me after my weekend brunch.   I have had French toast, scrambler, and omelette in Marigold, and they are just much more delicate than other brunch places in town. The French toast is definitely among the top 3 I had in my life. So much is said about this place in previous reviews, and I do not have too much to add.   If you have not been to this place, get in line and give it a try!

Great breakfast spot! Awesome vibe and space. We had the stuffed peppers which were amazing and so filling, and the sweet potato kale pesto hash which had lots of awesome flavors put together. Highly recommended place. We wish we could have had more room for some of the bakery options that looked delicious too.

This place is excellent. The food is delicious and very reasonably priced, considering the ingredients. I had the breakfast sandwich, which was very tasty and enough to satisfy a healthy appetite! I also had the orange juice, which was fresh squeezed and super good. The raves about the blueberry pancakes are spot-on! My boyfriend ordered these, and they're so good. The citrus butter is a great touch. It does have alcohol because you can get drinks like greyhounds and mimosas. I'd highly recommend this place!

The food is the best brunch in town, the coffee is wonderful, and the mimosas/greyhounds are delicious.  I love to come here for the ambiance. The music is fun and cheerful, and the interior is sunny. The servers are positive and helpful.  I think the model of ordering before you're seated is genius. Don't be scared off if it looks busy-- the line moves very quickly. You won't have to wait more than 10 minutes.  Protip: You MUST have the Marigold potatoes. They are God's gift to breakfast.

For whatever reason we expected a tired old diner with good food, boy were we wrong. Marigold is a hip, happening place with great food. We both had chilaquiles, excellent! The plates on the tables next to us looked great too. Looking forward to another visit!

My son lived in Madison for the last 2 years and took me here, saying it was his favorite breakfast spot. I dunno. Food is creative. I found it crowded and too hip. Duck confit hash was not as good as I expected. Fresh squeezed orange juice was nice, as was the green tea. Maybe 4 stars on a good day.

Best breakfast in Madison...HANDS DOWN! The eggs are unreal. Wish I knew the secret ingredient in the scrambled! My favorite, however, are the chile poached eggs. They are so incredible! A small portion that I like to pair with a short-stack of their specialty pancaked with mascarpone.   Prices are rather steep but once - or twice - in a while it's definitely okay to treat yourself to a Marigold breakfast.

Almost every time I eat at Marigold, I walk away unsatisfied. It's one of those places that some of my friends love, but is simply just not for me.  For instance, I tried their Tuna Melt today for lunch. It was edible, but not one of the better I've had. I didn't like the sweetness of the house-made pickles, nor the sliced tomato under the melted cheese. I didn't even get a hint of rosemary from the bread. I make a much better Tuna Melt at home with very minimal effort. The arugula salad on the side was fine, as was the cabbage salad. But, did I mention that this meal was $11? For it's averageness, it would be better priced at perhaps $8-9. I opted for the free water to keep my meal at a decent price.  My friend ordered one of their lunch specials (some sort of salad with beans and prosciutto) and also felt the $11 price was a bit much.  I've been more happy with brunch at Marigold, but never really felt like lunch was worth my time or money.   For brunch, I do like the their omelets, and their Chili Braised Chicken Sandwich is quite tasty. I've ordered their pancakes and their house-made granola, and those were both okay.  Overall, this is a decent place to eat once in awhile when someone suggests it. Otherwise...meh.

A very unique menu with a lot of out of the box breakfast options. I had the chorizo omelette and it was delicious, but the potatoes stole the show. Crispy and very flavorful. A friend had the duck hash and that was great, but the scrambler and the bacon omelette were a bit disappointing to the others dining with us. They serve bloody Marys during brunch and those also weren't great...especially at $7 each  This is a restaurant where customers order at the counter and serve themselves for drinks/coffee then are given a # and a member of the staff brings your food out. So, not full service and it can get busy making finding a table tricky.    Overall, it was decent but pretty expensive. For two of us, our meal was $45 (including one cocktail). Pretty pricey for "just OK" food.

Came here for Saturday brunch and narrowly missed the rush (got there 11ish)! Pretty much as soon as we got our food (which was quick), a line had started to form. I imagine the cold morning had discouraged people from getting there too early.  My friend and I both got the French toast and loved it. We got two different espresso drinks off the overhead coffee menu, and they were both delicious as well.   The ambience was nice and cozy, and the staff were very friendly.

Came here for breakfast on a Saturday morning around 10AM- basically your peak business time. The line from the counter went all the way to the from door, and we almost walked away, but a leaving patron told us the line went quickly, so we decided to wait it out. To her point, the line did move quickly. Within 10 minutes we had ordered, and only had to wait a few minutes to grab a table for four. The interior is downright adorable, very rustic-chic. It was a little loud in the space but hey, it was packed.   Both my fella & I got the breakfast sandwich, which did not disappoint. Fried egg, bacon, tomato, and an amazing gooey cheese on a really fresh roll. I love breakfast sandwiches, and if they aren't great, it's often because the sandwich feels bogged down by grease. This was NOT the case at Marigold! This was so light and fresh, the bread was delicious, bacon was crisp, and everything tasted great. Fairly big sandwich, definitely worth the $8 price tag. We also got mimosas which were a tad weak, but otherwise tasted great. I would absolutely come here again!

Marigold kitchen is a consistently good brunch place. I've  been many times and have always left pleased. It's a pretty casual spot since you order at a counter. I've had good luck with their specials. It can get packed on farmer's market weekends. On those days I'm not always sure it is worth the wait, but considering how busy they are they get the food out fast.
If you like sandwiches with crispy toasted bread, savory meats balanced well with slaw and a yummy dessert to finish it off, you'll love Marigold.

Easily one of the best places in Madison to get breakfast, Marigold's never disappoints with its gourmet omelettes and daily scrambles, blueberry pancakes topped with orange-almond butter, and fresh sandwiches and salads. Your first big decision will be to determine if your taste buds lean salty or sweet. The baked goods in the glass display next the the register will make you drool as you pay your bill, and go great with the coffee and fresh-squeezed juices on offer. In the summertime, its outdoor seating is an additional perk, but be prepared to wait regardless because this place has a good reputation in the city and is almost always packed on weekend mornings.

So my review is mixed. Before kids we did enjoy going here for breakfast but now...  It the past 4 years we have gone twice, both times more stressed out then we were before going in.   If your young or no toddlers with, have money to blow, don't care about small potions and the wait on Saturday this place wants you. For us we will have to stick with more family friendly restaurants.  This past Saturday we waited 40 minutes for under cooked French toast, short stack that our toddler was scared of. $28 (plus tip) for 3 meals that left us hungry and unsatisfied.

When I get a text that says "meet for brunch at noon" from my best friend, I don't even have to ask where. You only have to specify a location if you aren't going to Marigold.   Of course, there is one serious problem with Marigold. I end up having a heart-wrenching, philosophical dilemma every time I go there: savory or sweet? It would be an easy decision to make if one menu item from either camp stood out above the rest, but everything is so good! I don't even notice the wait because I spend the whole time I'm in line making a pros and cons list between two of the items in my head. It's all very emotional for me.  By the time I get to the front of the line, the turmoil I am experiencing is plain to see. The girl at the register asks me what I'll have and I just stammer, "ummm ummm ummm...." and begin to panic. But just when I start to hyperventilate, my friend jumps in. "We'll split the duck confit hash and the french toast."  That's why he's my best friend.

I love Marigold Kitchen. I just. love. it..  The service is pleasant. The food is inventive and tasty. The atmosphere is a-buzz with downtown energy. It's often hard to find a table and one out of 5 times I've been there, the food was only great (rather than fantastic) so that's the reason for the 1 star deduction. Still, one of my favorite lunch spots near the square. Their daily specials and soups are not to be missed. Also, amazing macaroons.

Maybe I had too high expectations after all the 5-stars this place has gotten, but I just wasn't blown away. We went for breakfast on a Thursday. Easy to find and parking wasn't a problem. We were a little confused when we first entered - didn't realize you order at the counter and take a number and find a table and the food is brought out. I tried the blueberry pancakes. I wanted to get a side of sausage - but was told something like they were cooking and it would be a long wait. First big negative - who runs out of sausage? Looking at others eating, it looks like I missed out too (they had sausage and it looked yummy). My wife got the Breakfast sandwich. Next two problems - my pancakes came with a "orange-almond butter" which sounds very cool. . . only problem is that is all I tasted. The orange taste was so overpowering that nothing else came through. My wife thought her sandwich had cream cheese on it - I think it was the boursin cheese. Both of us probably won't be ordering those items if we choose to return.  Now I will say that everything seemed very fresh and all natural. . . it was great atmosphere and service was fine. Pretty expensive though - for a breakfast - and portions were not large. Overall I wasn't impressed, but my friends say to try it again. I might - but I'm not in a hurry to return.

Based on the food alone, this place would be 4 stars based on what we had today. We were in town over the weekend, and breakfast is my favorite meal of the day.  My boyfriend googled and this place popped up on the Madison Better Breakfast Bureau (what a fantastic idea, by the way) -  so based on the ratings on that site and yelp, I was SUPER excited to eat there. So why such a low rating?  I really hated the set up.  It was this morning (Sunday) so I knew it was going to be crowded.  I thought it would be like a normal restaurant where you go, wait an excruciating amount of time for a table, and then sit down and have some time to look over the menu, decide what to get, and order.  No. That is not how it works... I felt very rushed the entire time I was there.  I felt as though I had 25 seconds to look at the menu.  Order, get a number and sit at a table and wait for the food. The coffee is self serve (which is not the part that is the problem) but is  in such an inconveniently located place directly next the to the cash register that it is super crowded, you can't get refills because the crazy line is ALWAYS in front of it.  And I'm sorry, but if I'm paying $2.25 for a "bottomless" cup of coffee, that means I want a refill.  And I was under the impression the term "bottomless" stems from a waitress coming over and refilling your cup before you see the bottom... Anyway - no way to get refills of your coffee... Moving on -  I was also sitting at a table directly near the coffee station, and where the food comes up from the kitchen (and also located directly next to the seats where people who have already ordered and are waiting for tables are sitting).  My chair was bumped no less than 30 times by people walking back and forth (staff and customers alike).   Now - about the people waiting for tables - I am eating my breakfast.  I do NOT want you staring down at me because you have already ordered and are waiting for your food.  It makes me feel uncomfortable, and made me eat faster, and not really enjoy my meal.   That is not their fault, but rather the fault of the set up of the restaurant.  Perhaps you should not have people order food before they definitely have a table.   Overall, it was just very odd.  I would definitely not return based on the set up..  The food was great (Ham and Gruyere Omelet for me, Chorizo scrambler for boyfriend).

The menu here makes everything sound delicious. I ordered the quiche which was described as having andouille sausage, broccoli, red peppers and Gouda. I ordered a side of Marigold potatoes because the quiche only came with greens. The handsome man I was with ordered the duck confit hash.   Only the potatoes were tasty. My quiche was bland, even the sausage had minimal flavor. The crust was overly dense and chewy, not at all flaky. There was no Gouda to be found. I never season my food at restaurants but it needed salt and quite a bit of pepper.   The duck confit hash looked greasy and disgusting. The potatoes were not even cooked through, I could barely get a fork in the piece he gave me. I did not try it but he also had to douse it in salt and pepper for it to be edible. There were strange pieces of something in the hash that looked like melted plastic and had the same texture. He left those on the plate. The hash only came with greens, no toast. Toast was an extra $2.50. We did not order any.   The potatoes were a nice mix of crispy and soft with just enough greasiness to enhance the flavor.   My companion also ordered a Bloody Mary and they suggested the heirloom mix. It tasted like puréed fresh tomatoes with tons of seeds and no depth of flavor. It was horrible and he didn't even finish half.   They never came back to check on us after bringing the food, so we didn't have the opportunity to share our disappointment. We also had to borrow salt and pepper from the table next to us  The decor is cute and everything LOOKS tasty, it just really lacked flavor. We were very disappointed especially after spending over $35 on breakfast.

I came here for breakfast on Sunday morning with a small group. I got one of their special plates - Pork Tacos and a chai tea latte. I was very satisfied with my choices. The plate came with two tacos, black beans and two eggs cooked to your liking. This kept me full until for a good half of day. The restaurant and staff are nice. You order up front, get a number and they bring the food out to you. There is outdoor seating as well as tables inside and chairs at the counter. You help yourself to water and can only get a table once you order and have a number. Overall, a good experience that I would recommend.

Loved this little place. We went for breakfast on a Saturday morning. They were very busy but still friendly and efficient. Didn't have to wait long for a table. On weekends and busy days it appears you order at counter then hostess finds a table for you. I had the scrambler with eggs, roasted red peppers, sweet potatoes and kale. It was served with potatoes, toast and a little salad. Salad unusual with breakfast but hey I liked it! My husband had an omelette with rosemary bread toast. He raves about it. Our friends also enjoyed their meals. If I lived in Madison I would be a regular.

One the better places to get breakfast in town. They're potatoes are very flavorful. Their pancakes are also very good but I like their savory items. Their breakfast sandwich is also very good! Great sauce with tomatoes and all kinds of fixings. I will note that the last couple times I've gone, the flavor of the food is not as bold....hope they're not getting complacent...

Marigold earns 5 stars from me for their breakfast sandwich! The cheddar-spiked Boursin is soooo good. This sandwich is flavorful and filling without being greasy. Awesome!   Today I tried an omelette (zucchini, goat cheese, and red pepper) along with mixed greens, breakfast potatoes, and rosemary toast. The omelette was pretty good, the greens were lightly dressed and very fresh, the potatoes were tasty (large portion). The rosemary toast was good but nothing game changing.   From this day forward, I plan to order a breakfast sandwich and will try to convince my dining partners to order potatoes and mixed greens to share. Yum!

Being from Chicago it was refreshing to be in a breakfast place that cared about the flavor of the food instead of the quantity. The French toast was complete with strawberries, blueberries, raspberries and blackberries, along with creaming glaze and topped with toasted almost slices. My boyfriend had the Duck Confit Hash, the upper portion of duck to potato was in the ducks favor, which was highly enjoyable for him. The small spring salad that comes with it was a nice palate cleanser and the eggs were buttery and fluffy. Was a wonderful experience and will be back but it received a 4 only because it was cramped.

For a quick meal it can't be beat. We shared a caesar salad, which was done just right. I tried the veggie sandwhich, but think it would have been better if it wasn't served cold. I really like their sister restaurant, Sardines. Both have nice outdoor patios.

Loved everything here! I got there black iced coffee which was so refreshingly good. I also got the chilaquiles and my friends got the salmon frittata and the duck hash which were all very delicious! The chilaquiles were a bit spicy though but I love spicy so it was perfect for me! I came here on a Mon morning and it was not packed at all. There were only about 4 people ahead of us in line.

The food here is quite delicious and I probably come here for breakfast (usually to go) once or twice every two weeks. That said, the potatoes are covered in oil and while yummy, I feel guilty after I eat them every time (keep in mind, this continued to not stop me from ordering). Scrambled eggs come more like an omelette than true scrambled eggs - seems to be what a lot of breakfast places do but it still drives me crazy. They're still yummy to eat, though. I will never come here close to lunch because there is nowhere to sit down. I visit on early weekday mornings and that's about it. Regardless of when I come, the line to order seems to take longer than it takes to get the food. As such, if I eat in and want to get a second mimosa or anything at all, it requires getting back up in line and going through all over again - no thanks. I would still recommend it to people looking for a good, non-diner weekday breakfast joint, but I've been limiting my visits recently for all the reasons above.

If you don't mind waiting in line for what is one of the best brunch places in town, then you won't be disappointed. The pumpkin buckwheat pancakes made my taste buds soar, and the mulled cider had me begging for another cup. I can't wait to return, because I have my eye on the duck confit hash.

We wanted to go to marigolds but the wait was an hour & we were hungry.  We went close to when they opened too.  I could tell their menu was better.   The old fashioned gets a low score because they don't have even one omelet  to offer.  How is that possible for a breakfast place?

Yummy food and good service.   We enjoyed iced coffees, braised pork, quiche, and the divine buttermilk pancakes. The pancakes were incredible. Husband loved the braised pork.   My only complaint was my quiche. While it was a very tasty quiche -- and very reasonably priced for such a huge slice -- the crust was soggy. I have no formal training with cooking/baking, and I'm just a home cook -- but my quiche crust at home has never turned out that badly. Also, strangely, one single bite from my quiche at Marigold Kitchen was very cold.  I would return and make sure to eat the buttermilk pancakes again and try something other than the quiche.

Good selection overall.  We had a great breakfast sandwich, excellent if not messy fish tacos and good brunch drinks.  Friendly and professional staff.  Sit outside if you want peace and quiet with your eggs but the vibe and buzz inside is excellent.
Such an adorable place- the workers are kind and food is amazing. Went on a Sunday and stood in a huge line, but it went fast. A place like this surely cares for its customers!
Great restaurant! Went here for breakfast and was truly impressed with the service and the food! Fresh ingredients and great coffee.

The wait was long and it was crowded- however: the servers were calm and organized. The drink options were many and delicious. I got the artichoke and sun dried tomato omelette- so yum. You must get the coconut macaroon as well!

I stopped here on a road trip while passing through Madison. Nice spot, good food. I was a little confused when I walked in and didn't know I was the place my order at the counter then seat myself. The blueberry pancakes were very sweet. I loved the Wisconsin maple syrup with them. I also really enjoyed the egg plate. The potatoes were very flavorful and so was The rosemary toast! Between the sweet and savory, I may have had too many flavors going on, so be careful of that...otherwise, great meal!
Delish! One of the best brunches I've ever had. I had the artichoke omelet and it was wonderful. Staff is very delightful as well!

During my first experience here, I walked in craving brunch 4 MINUTES after they stopped serving brunch, and they refused to serve me. Really?? 4 EFFING minutes means that much to you, Marigold? And the pretentious hipster douche half my age behind the counter just sneered at me like I was outrageous for politely asking them to lighten the F up and make an exception.  I guess they're not hurting for business so they can turn it away if you want brunch 4 minutes after they stop serving it. Or maybe the punk-a$$ behind the counter majored in accordion and will be living with mom and dad for the next 50 years and this is the most authority they will ever wield in life? By laying down the law for those who have the ovaries to walk in 4 minutes late and ask for some damn eggs and pancakes. SHEESH! I thought about asking for a manager but honestly, with that major attitude from the cashier, I was pretty sure someone would spit in our food. We walked out and spent our money somewhere around the corner...somewhere that serves brunch an entire HOUR later than Marigold did/does.  I'm giving them 2 stars instead of 1 because I returned 3-4 years later (I know how to hold a grudge). I made sure to show up well before they stopped serving brunch. Cashier was new and polite. Server was wonderful. We sat outside and I had some pretty great blueberry pancakes, and an egg scramble thing that was pretty darn good, along with a fantastic mimosa. I don't think I'd ever want to eat inside though...the acoustics are TERRIBLE and you can't hear what the person across from you is saying. FWIW I've had my hearing tested and it is WAY above average. It's just bad interior sound design on their part.  I will probably go here again if the stars align just perfectly, but after that first experience with the pretentious jerk I doubt it'll be anytime soon. Some of my friends have had negative experiences here too. Which is a shame because we all agreed the food is very good. But the noisy interior and the crappy attitude of uppity service staff isn't something I want to reward with money. There are so many other restaurants and food carts to try in Madison. Like I said earlier, I don't think they're worried about getting and keeping your business. Marigold is NEVER my first choice. But when it worked out it was very good.

I like to eat here for lunch. Their brunch is hugely popular but I don't have the patience for that. The staff is friendly, the food is excellent and there are good choices for vegetarians. I had them cater a lunch for a small group and that was excellent as well.

This place had the perfect size short stack. It was also came with an orange infused syrup. Yummy!  Not only that, but their dark mocha was awesome. It wasn't too rich...perfectly blended over ice! Great way to start off a nice humid summer madison morning!

This place was packed! Line out the door makes it a longer and more crowded experience, so expect to wait a bit for weekend brunch. Food quality was good and matched the price. They have coffee and drinks (I had a bloody) and good breakfast like pancakes, omelets and scrambles. Not much competition nearby as it's location is right near the Capitol.

Love this place. Bright fun loving relaxed interior decor, great prices and awesome food.  It's usually crowded...because it's so good.  Order at counter, take a number, grab any open table, get food right off the grill. Aim for the breakfast sandwich or scrambler.  Self serve water and coffee. Relaxed, not formal.

Alright, so I have mixed reviews.  I find it easier to list them:  1. Great eggs/scrambler/omelette. Fresh, hot, delicious. 2. TERRIBLE potatoes. Borderline inedible. My potatoes were burnt the first time I went. The second time? Too cold and flavorless to eat. 3. Great options for having such a small menu. I tried the French Rosemary bread and fell in love. I was really impressed that they offered something so out of the box. It was a great change of pace. However, the bread is served cold. It is like they toast it earlier in the day and them slightly warm it when they serve you. 4. The lavender infused espresso drinks. Fabulous. I had the White Chocolate Lavender Mocha and it was simply heaven. Divine. Amazing. Should I continue?  I can not decide what I love more, the aroma or the flavor. I have also had the Honey Lavender Latte. That one trumps its mocha friend. Here is my issue. These are all specials that only last a week. This depresses me because I love them all and never get them again. Now, I know they are small and need to change things up, but love is love. And I miss the drinks. 5. Timing. I get it, you are busy. However, I really get annoyed that my food beats my coffee out by several minutes.

Marigold Kitchen is one of my favorite places for brunch in Madison. They have great food and a fun atmosphere. You order the counter and then sit down. Usually there is a line to the door on the weekends but it is a pretty quick turnaround. They have amazing chai lattes and bloody Mary's. I've never had a bad meal here and they have a good selections of pastries and cookies for desert.

I was impressed with the food at Marigold Kitchen because the flavors and tastes contrasted and complimented well with one another. My brunch meal consisted of a salmon omelet, filled with salty salmon filet and cream cheese, that was perfectly paired with a small salad dressed in a balsamic vinaigrette and a side of sliced Russet potatoes. The only critique about my meal is that the creamy, melt-in-your-mouth cream cheese inside the omelet could've been distributed more evenly--it was a bit gross to bite suddenly into a thick dollop of sweetness when the egg and salmon was salty. It also seems to be constantly busy and crowded with people streaming through the doors.
The food was very good. However, for the price I do not like the fact that I need to wait in line to order and then bus the table. If prices were lower I'd be fine with it but don't prefer it here.

Stopped for breakfast at Marigold's. Their self-serve coffee was pretty good and it was nice that it was bottomless. I had a short stack of the blueberry pancakes. They were also pretty good, but the pancakes were pretty small (two pancakes the size of my palm) for the nearly $7 price.   Their breakfast potatoes are unusual though not unpleasant; they are thin, crisp potatoes heavily seasoned with herbs. The place can get pretty busy on weekend mornings, so be sure to bring your patience.

I think the thing that stands out for me from Marigold is the service. Yes, the have absolutely delicious food and the coffee is great. The atmosphere is cozy-casual, but man, the service made the experience for me.  I have an aversion to onions. I don't have an allergy, but I do not like them in any form, not raw, not caramelized, not pickled, no way, no how do I eat onions. And at Marigold I want to order the breakfast sandwich which comes with a fried egg, cheddar-spiked boursin, applewood smoked bacon, tomato and green onion on toasted ciabatta. I asked for no green onions. While they aren't on my strict no-onions list I still choose not to have them when possible. However, they were mixed in with the cheddar-spiked boursin and therefore not removable. I hemmed and hawed but the man at the counter said it would be good and if it wasn't he would give me something else so I took it.  I ended up eating about half of it, not because I didn't like it, but just because I was full. However, the man from the counter came over toward the end of our breakfast and expressed concern about the amount of the sandwich I hadn't eaten. He tried to get me to order something else and apologized if I didn't enjoy my breakfast. I did, in fact, enjoy my breakfast. But, man. The fact that he remembered me and checked in based on how much I ate was really nice. And so, I'd go back for the service if nothing else. But, in reality I'd also go back to try the pancakes because those looked fantastic.

I love getting the chicken salad but this time they made it with half of the ingredients. I felt completely ripped off for paying $12 for greens and 4 chunks of chicken with 1 chunk of cheese. The quality was definitely not there this time. Not sure if I will return.

I got a French toast here and it is by far the best french toast I have gotten. It is delicious and with fresh fruit such as strawberries, blueberries and blackberries. The syrup was also hot and went well with the toast.

Let me start by saying I m not in love with cafeteria style service so I have a bias walking in the door.  I ordered the marigold sandwich which was good. My wife had blueberry pancakes I didn't love there pancake batter.  Tasted a little sour for my liking.  There coffee is strong. Good location to the Hilton.

Brunch was delicious. The baked goods are especially noteworthy. And my pancake craving was definitely satisfied.  But be warned if you are planning on grabbing a meal here on a weekend, plan on waiting in line in a bizarre Soup Nazi style seating system. You see, since you order at the counter, you'd think finding a table would be first come first serve like most any other restaurant on the planet where you order at the counter. Instead, finding a table or even a seat at the bar and then ordering is verboten. Instead you will be instructed to order your food first and then look around sheepishly for somewhere to sit and eat it. I imagine on normal days this isn't a problem, but for weekend brunch, it means you might find yourself with a plate of delicious brunch items and nowhere to consume it.   The effect of course is to give the dining experience a conveyer belt quality in which you feel rushed to eat and go. At the very least, you find yourself averting your eyes from the poor souls standing around eying your plates and checking their watches. Basically the opposite of what brunch is supposed to be like: leisurely.   But again, the food itself was delicious.

Went for breakfast while wives were doing the farmers market. The line stretched out the door but moved quickly.  We placed our order within 10 minutes- were seated and eating within 20 minutes. Had OJ , EGGS, BACON, BUTTERMILK PANCAKES.  Everything was perfect- definitely found a new breakfast location.

I loved everything i got here! Its really nice to have the option of a short stack for pancakes, because if you are really hungry you can order something else too! I got the poached eggs with prosciutto and manchego cheese. Ot was great!!! Nice atmosphere and service too. It is pricey but worth it

This place is great for breakfast, brunch, or lunch. The menu is creative and all the ingredients are very fresh.  It can be very crowded for brunch, but it is definitely worth it.  Not to mention the bloody mary's and unlimited coffee are great bonuses.    I always get the omelette with goat cheese and zucchini, but there are about 7 other omelette options alone. The potatoes that are served with the entree are crazy good.    Very friendly, quick service.
Great food but so busy and loud I couldn't really enjoy my company. Will definitely be back but it's not the place to go for a heart to heart chat.

Delicious stop for breakfast while visiting Madison! I got the broccoli and mushroom omelette and the maple latte. OMG so good!!!! The latte and omelette were amazing and the hash browns that came with the omelette were probably the best I've ever had! I will probably have a dream or two about that breakfast and definitely would return if I'm in Madison again

It was okay. Buttermilk pancakes were crepe-like and pretty sour. Too much buttermilk for me. Side of beans was HUGE but they were very bland. Nitro coffee was decent. I had much better breakfasts at Short Stack and the Brunch Club.
Great frittata and buckwheat pancakes.  Highly recommended.  Nice decor. Prompt service.

Madison no doubt has some of the best egg sandwiches out there. I'd only ever had McDonald's egg mcmuffin (a zillion years ago, mind you), so perhaps my expectations weren't all that high. But my oh my, Marigold Kitchen's egg sandwich is one of the best I've had since moving to Madison a year ago. Would of gotten five stars had the bacon been cooked a little longer.  For a side I purchased potatoes, which I generally would douse in ketchup - but there was enough flavor where, dare I say it, my favorite condiment was not necessary.   Tried the Peppermint Mocha with Soy. Not a fan. Boyfriend enjoyed the coffee, but wished there was more of a selection rather than just one Regular or Decaf carafe. The unlimited refills made up for his griping, though.

We had a nice brunch here. Food and service was good. I ate the barley saute with a fried egg on top. The marigold potatoes were the best part of the meal, but very greasy. The heirloom bloody mary was one of the best I've had.

Marigold is a great place to meet for lunch.  Cafeteria style with a very creative menu.  Lovely salads and interesting sandwiches.  When it is crowded it can be noisy so head for a table at the windows or along the back wall.  And sit back and enjoy the excellent food.  Also great for breakfast and brunch.

Unique, cool place to enjoy a meal.  I'm so happy they are now open for bunch on Sunday Mornings (before it was only Saturday).  Why I go here: *Fresh orange juice -mmm *Good coffee *Duck hash (any many other interesting menu items) *Potato side is killer *Yummy pastries *Fun casual atmosphere, usually busy  Note: I would not bring a group of more than 4 or 6 people here- it gets busy.
Best brunch in Madison, and they have a ton of competition. Duck Confit hash is too good

A favorite of the capitol square crowd.  It's been packed every time I've been there for lunch.  Order at the counter and fight for a seat.  The salads are huge, but everything is just a little pricey...something common around the square.  Nice cushions and pillows on the benches around the restaurant.  Nothing too stand out, but a great lunch staple for a salad or sandwich with a few baked goods as well. 4 stars.

My favorite breakfast/brunch spot in Madison. Very tasty options and good brunch (read: alcoholic) drinks, too. I like the French toast, or breakfast sandwich if I'm in the mood for savory. Always a bustling place but it doesn't take long to get seated after you order. It can feel a little chaotic when you first walk in but the staff manages it well. It's a little pricey but worth it in my opinion.   Sitting outside on a farmers market day is awesome! If it's a nice day, definitely try to get a spot outside.

Best breakfast in town with something for everyone, made with fresh, healthy, delicious ingredients that you can't get anywhere else- from salmon and cream cheese omelets to french toast covered with berries to a great breakfast sandwich.    Lunch is the same variety and quality and it's definitely worth it to substitute the homemade potato salad for the coleslaw...the portions are filling and worth the price and every recipe from the salads to the burger to the pesto grilled cheese has been created with the most attention to detail.
Better Cinnamon Sugar Donut Muffins!?  AMAZING!!!  I want some right now, that would be good. Believe It!

Marigold's breakfast is a treat for anyone who lives or works downtown.  The food is just so fresh!  Their pancakes, French toast, and eggs are great, but my favorite is their breakfast sandwich, which I order without meat.  The breakfast sandwich also works well for carryout; it gets so darn crowded that I'd rather take my food with me when possible.  If you want to eat in with some friends or family, go early!  The later it gets, the more crowded it will be.  The one thing that bugs me about Marigold is that they stop serving breakfast at 10:30 on the dot, which isn't very clear on their website, and they can be pretty merciless to anyone standing in line at that time.  I've had my dreams of brioche French toast dashed more than once.  I do wish they had more vegetarian sandwiches, and that they served some of their veggie sandwiches and salads  on Saturday.  They have the best greens of any restaurant in the area.
great place for brunch. nice atmostphere

Food is good, love the decor and atmosphere, but I feel the prices are a little much for soups and sandwiches.  Definitely filling and satisfying, but pretty hard on the wallet for a quick little lunch.

Somehow in all my time in Madison (6 years), I had never managed to check this place out. What was I missing out on!? Deliciousness. That's what.  Marigold Kitchen is an unassuming business on the Capitol Square that knows how to do breakfast. It has great coffee options, a variety of breakfast options, and an efficient system to get everyone eating.  My friend and I came basically at opening on a Saturday, which was wise. It filled up fast! I had a quiche, which was fantastic. The crust was just killer. I'll come back again and again!

Perfect casual breakfast spot for families.  You order at the counter, it is super casual, fast and great vibe.  I cannot eat gluten (celiac) and found several items that I could have that are naturally GF.  I talked with the employee at the counter for a bit and they seemed to know what they were doing.

The Duck Confit Hash was excellent, even though I've found that duck is not my prime choice of meat for breakfast!   It is a little pricier than other breakfast spots and very tough for a group to find seating but they know how to do breakfast right!
I had the grilled turkey and cheese with figs for lunch and a side of red cabbage.  Good stuff!  During lunchtime, it gets crowded.

This breakfast place was recommended to me by a local Madison resident. It did not disappoint! My only complaint is that it felt a bit rushed, as you order at the counter and then find a table. I like a more leisurely brunch!  My boyfriend and I split the egg sandwich with a side of potatoes and fruit. The sandwich consisted of a fried egg, bacon, cheese, fresh tomato and chive cream cheese all on a ciabatta roll. It had such great flavor! The potatoes were so delicious, too. The fruit was very fresh!  I was also a big fan of the coffee. This place is really cute and I would return!

Great central location-helpful staff.  Breakfast sandwich and zucchini, red pepper goat cheese omelette were delicious. Coffee is excellent.  I would return in a heartbeat although very loud music under speakers in several spots would lead me to sit outside. Very very busy at 10am on a Friday: how noisy would it be on a weekend? Ditch the music- the sound of happy customers is the best music of all.

Great affordable brunch food. Love is definitely cooked into every bite here.   Their coffee drinks are also great, nothing like an iced almond milk latte.   I had a burger and it was one of the best decisions I've made in a while.   I'm not giving them five stars because my group of seven had to sit with six chairs at a four person table. I know it's busy, and we are all pretty relaxed people, but come on!

The staff are very friendly and attentive. The French toast is really subpar and soggy. The tropical pineapple pancake was delicious. Their poached eggs are dry....which is weird for poached eggs.  Their kids menu "little chick" is $7 - that's overpriced when neither or my kids were able to even eat half their food because they said it "tastes weird"- they have had many French toast and pancakes in their lives.  Their coffee tastes stale no depth.  Their "fresh squeezed orange juice" tasted like concentrated orange juice- there is a stark difference between fresh squeezed and not fresh squeezed in taste/ that really is so wrong.  Sorry this sounds so negative but we went here because of all the great reviews- so we were pretty disappointed.  I hope my review helps others.

Better than average food. Cute little place for Bunch, and the quality is outstanding. Very wholesome, and fresh. Coffee is decent, not fantastic. Staff is very friendly. Try the french toast, the berries are really fresh and delicious.

Went there for my bi-annual brunch with a couple friends. Wow. Totally delicious!  I got the omelet with chorizo, roasted red peppers, sweet corn relish, cheddar cheese and cilantro.  The veggies were ultra-fresh, the cheese nice and sharp, and that oh-so-delicious cilantro tied the whole omelet together. Their potatoes are pretty awesome, too.  Oh yeah, and the servers are INSANELY friendly, unpretentious...it's a wonderful place to grab brunch, sit back and relax. I loved it!  NOW, to be fair--I can't give it five stars because, well, Sophia's...but keep this in mind--it's pretty damn excellent food.

In my three days visiting Madison, I came here twice.  As a person that likes to try as many different places as possible, this doesn't happen too much.  However, this place really is awesome.  Ok, yes, it's crowded for weekend brunch.  They are kinda slow in making the food.  But it makes sense.  The food is REALLY good.  I tried the scrambler, which came with the marigold potatoes and toast (I got the rosemary bread).  This morning, I got the french toast (came with maple syrup, sweet cream and fresh berries).  Both were awesome, and next time I'm in Madison, I'll be sure to go back!

Great breakfast, close to Capitol, but there are cheaper options  Ate at Marigold with my family during a Labor Day visit to Madison. You need to wait in line to order and pay for your food. The line was pretty intimidating, but surprisingly, it goes pretty quickly. The food was more expensive than what I expected for Madison. It was fresh and good, but we found some cheaper options during the rest of our stay.

There were four in our party for brunch.  And it was another 10 on a Sunday morning, so a very busy time.    The breakfast sandwiches had green onion and cream cheese which didn't agree too well with part of or group   The breakfast potatoes weren't anything special.  In fact they were a bit soggy  Overall, it was "ok."  Not a place I'm in a hurry to get back to.  There are quite a few other brunch spots waiting to be tried.  Oh yeah.  There was no sugar-free syrup.  Really?

Probably my favorite brunch place in Madison. Converted a couple people to liking brunch simply from their great experiences here. What else is a better compliment to their food and atmosphere?  My standard staples: the breakfast sandwich (literally the perfect combo. Don't even like tomatoes and I like how they taste in this sandwich!), side of breakfast potatoes (just a little kick that even my spice-wary friends appreciate), and their iced tea. Classic, delicious, and keeps me full and happy... until the next meal. Their service is wonderful, and I have yet to wait more than 20-25 minutes for a table (and that's on a bad day. Though admittedly I rarely go with more than 3-4 people). During the summer, the outside tables are coveted spaces and well worth it, especially when the farmers market is happening on Saturdays!  Pro-tip if you love their iced tea. 1) You can get free refills, and 2) they are AMAZING and will fill you a separate cup to take to go. What could be better?!

I have been coming to Marigold for years and this was going to be a five-star review, but they made a recent, disturbing change--they switched from Anchora coffee to Alterra. Before you get up in arms, yelling, "I love Alterra," let me explain that Alterra is not a bad coffee, it's just that I loved the Anchora Marigold Special Blend. We would buy this blend and give it away to friends and family as presents.  I can understand making the change, and I will still LOVE Marigold, but now that I don't get my Marigold rocket fuel anymore, I will be a little less excited about going there.  As usual the food was excellent. I had the chorizo omlette with greens potatoes and toast.  This Saturday morning it was the usual buzzing/active/perfect-for-people-watching/too-loud-for-some atmosphere that I have grown to love.  I will miss you Anchora Marigold Special Blend. May you rest in peace.

Had no idea what we were going to do for breakfast and as the hotel guide stated in its first line "start with an energizing breakfast at the marigold", why not.   Wonderful breakfast sandwich, bacon, egg and lots of slurpy goodness washed down with a dark chocolate mocha mmmm. The rest of the family had quiche, French toast and bacon omelette and all cleared their plates, except Jim who didn't like the riot of fruit loaded on top of his toast (most would). Overall a damn yummy breakfast and will very likely be back on the travels to try some more.

I have had the duck confit, toasted coconut pancakes, vanilla lattes, chai lattes, and French toast.  The french toast is one of the best things I have ever had.  Seriously, I think it may go down for me as last meal on earth.  Everything here is superb, just excellent.  You know, it's strange - or maybe I'm just lucky - but every time I go to Marigold it is packed, line out the door packed and bustling like you would not believe. And yet.... Every time I get done ordering I am able to find a seat immediately.  They have fresh squeezed OJ, the lattes are excellent, and I love the atmosphere.  My all time favorite brunch spot in Madison.  I crave them every weekend, and want to try everything on the menu.  If only that french toast didn't keep calling me out, I may be able to get to those other items.

I do not give out five stars easily, but to validate my stars I can honestly say I eat here weekly, if not multiple times a week. I recommend whatever the special scrambler is of the moment, with an add on of a short stack of the speciality pancakes. Today it was ginger pancakes (yes. ginger pancakes- see?) and a three egg scrambler with yada yada awesome. If you want to order from the traditional menu the furthest I can get you is the Tostada. Just order it, they'll know what you mean! It's delicious and it's as far as I got on the menu before I fell in love, now i will only feed myself upon their specialty scramblers or a Tostada. Fun fact, they have the second best coconut macaroons in town (my absolute favorite). Any of the baked goods are great, you'll see them in the front case. They often showcase scones/breads/muffins with traditional sweet elements paired with more traditionally savory spices/herbs (for example: rosemary strawberry scones : )).

My absolute favorite brunch in Madison. I love coming here for brunch with the ladies after a night out to catch up and ease our hangovers with coffee and mimosas. I always order the ham and gruyere omelet with rosemary toast. It's fricken fantastic!

This place around the corner from the State House was a Mari-Gold mine of a find! The Chef de Cuisine Kristy Schwinn has created a well thought-out, flavorful menu!  Under the recommendation of the host I chose the Stuffed Poblano Pepper, its was an amazing gastronomic experience in my mouth! The flavor combinations of that dish where so well thought out I couldn't get enough of it!   Thank you ladies for making my first visit there a memorial to high quality ingredients and cooks!  I the famous words of Arnold Schwarzenegger "I'll Be Back" you can count on it!!

The breakfast sandwich here is my favorite in Madison. It's absolutely delicious.  I also always enjoy the pleasant wait staff. They are super friendly and seem to enjoy their jobs, which makes the atmosphere great!

Everything about this place made us feel welcome and delighted. Great atmosphere, clean, good service and excellent food. Salmon Fritata is a must order as it is fresh, fluffy and flavorful.  The espresso drink i orders contained local honey and spices and was presented in such a lovely way that i almost didn't want to drink it. So pretty.  We could tell the barista takes pride in his creations. Pancakes where dense, in a good way.  Thanks Marigold! We'll be back.

Treat yourself to breakfast here. Fluffiest and most flavorful pancakes ever! Top that with fresh strawberries, real maple syrup and a sprinkle of powdered sugar and you have a winner. You won't leave Marigold Kitchen disappointed or hungry.

This place is totally Madison rich people food. It's expensive but delicious. There are only a few meat options, but that means it's vegetarian friendly. It's not full service, so not full tipping makes it cheaper (though most people will tip the same here anyways. Way to work the market). The place is always full for brunch so that means you're at a place that other people want to eat. If you get tired of the long lines to wait through you can always people watch. It's all eccentric people and pretty girls.  TLDR; If you like five star reviews you'll like this place.

Fantastic, quick brunch spot. You walk up to the counter to order and then they bring your food to you, with self serve coffee, water and silverware. Small menu but interesting with really fresh ingredients, and plenty of vegetarian options. It was busy but they move people through pretty quickly. The potatoes have spices and a kick, which I love, and both egg dishes I sampled were delicious. Great option.
Great downtown breakfast spot. Delicious and cheap eats!

HIDDEN GEM OF BRUNCH IN DOWNTOWN MADISON.  Super delicious house made breakfasts and lunches (with coffee bar) featuring seasonal Wisconsin products. I'm partial to the pancakes and french toast served or else their specials for the day are A+ Get here early on weekends (8am) to snag a seat, it is limited during the winter. They usually will offer outdoor seating in the summers, great to stop by before the Farmers Market
Love this place! The heirloom Bloody Marys are amazing. Just a little spice and a lot of flavor. You really can't go wrong with anything on the menu and the staff is super friendly and helpful.

My experience at Marigold Kitchen was one of the highlights of my weekend away from Chicago.  I visited Madison a week ago, and I am still salivating over the deliciousness of my meal at Marigold!  I had the grilled Angus hamburger with gruyere - incredible!  I usually add ketchup to burgers, but with one bite in, I knew I wouldn't need any.  My burger was juicy and perfectly medium-rare, with the right ratio of meat to veggies to bun.  It wasn't too greasy (like many burgers can get) and it was well put together. And the sauce!  My mouth had a most pleasant after taste (strange, but true), and I have to say that this was truly one of the best burgers I have ever eaten.  My friend ordered a grilled cheese and gazpacho soup.
